title: 106_s1808
content: The Act may be cited as the "Drug Court Reauthorization and Improvement Act of 1999". Grant authority is established. The Attorney General may provide grants for programs involving judicial supervision over non-violent offenders with substance abuse issues, integrated with sanctions and services like testing, treatment, and supervised release options. The Attorney General may provide grants for programs involving judicial supervision over non-violent offenders with substance abuse issues, integrated with sanctions and services like testing, treatment, and supervised release options. The grants also cover programmatic, offender management, and aftercare services such as relapse prevention, health care, education, vocational training, job placement, housing placement, and family support services for participants in need. The Attorney General ensures an equitable geographic distribution of grant awards. SEC. 3. PROHIBITION OF PARTICIPATION BY VIOLENT OFFENDERS. The Attorney General will issue regulations to prevent violent offenders from participating in programs funded under this Act and will suspend funding if violent offenders are found to be involved. SEC. 4. DEFINITION. The term "violent offender" in this Act refers to a person charged or convicted of an offense involving the use of a firearm, causing death or serious bodily injury, or using force against another person. It also includes individuals with prior felony convictions for violent crimes intending to cause harm. SEC. 5. ADMINISTRATION. The Attorney General will consult with relevant officials, utilize Department of Justice components, issue necessary regulations, and require grant applications to include specific details and assurances of federal funds supplementing state resources. The proposal for funding must identify related initiatives, consult with affected agencies, have designated judges for supervision, plan for post-Federal support, and describe the evaluation methodology. To request funds under this Act, the chief executive or chief justice of a State, local government, or Indian tribal government must submit an application to the Attorney General. The Federal share of a grant may not exceed 75 percent of the total program costs unless waived by the Attorney General. In-kind contributions and non-Federal funds can count towards the non-Federal share of a grant. The Grantee Report must be submitted by States, Indian tribal governments, or local governments receiving funds under this Act to the Attorney General annually in March. The Attorney General is required to report to the House and Senate Judiciary Committees on the effectiveness of drug court programs and the management of those programs, as well as the drug relapse and recidivism rates of offenders participating in programs authorized by this Act. Technical assistance, training, and evaluation are also provided under Section 9 of the Act. The Attorney General may provide technical assistance, training, and evaluations for programs under this Act. This can be done directly or in collaboration with other entities. Additionally, a Center for Substance Abuse Treatment is established under Section 10. The Center for Substance Abuse Treatment is authorized to receive $75,000,000 annually from 2000 to 2003 to provide drug treatment services in conjunction with drug court programs. The Attorney General is authorized to receive $200,000,000 annually from 2000 to 2003 for implementing sections 2 through 9 of the Act.
